line: Watson and Crick's Nobel Prize winning paper on the double helix was only one page.

line: Long papers drain intellectual energy from both readers and writers and waste
label: heading

line: their time.
label: heading

line: They take longer to write, and much of the energy in writing them is dedicated to sections
label: paragraph

line: that don't engage the writer: Writing is a powerful tool to solve problems, and can result
label: paragraph

line: in substantial cognitive development (it can make you smarter), but to do this, the writing
label: paragraph

line: must be directed at a difficult problem (Langer and Applebee, 1987).
label: paragraph

line: Long papers take longer to read. Even readers who try to skim long papers have to
label: paragraph

line: devote time and energy to find the essential parts, and run the danger of missing the
label: paragraph

line: details.

line: A Disservice to the Profession and to the Scholar
label: heading

line: Too-long papers hurt the spread of knowledge in two ways: They waste our time in both
label: paragraph

line: reading and writing, and they promote sloppy reading. Many readers are content just to
label: paragraph

line: read the abstract and perhaps the summary of technical papers, with a glance at a table.
label: paragraph

line: This means, of course, that significant details on methodology and the analysis, buried in
label: paragraph

line: the paper, are missed, and crucial points and often errors are perpetuated.
label: paragraph

line: Too-long papers also take up space. A journal with five too-long papers could easily
label: paragraph

line: include 20 short papers. This space limitation hurts the dissemination of knowledge,
label: paragraph

line: because less genuine information is available, and makes it much harder for junior
label: paragraph

line: scholars to publish and to get tenure and promotion, especially when universities require
label: paragraph

line: publication in certain journals. This problem will be alleviated as more journals are done
label: paragraph

line: on the internet, of course.
label: paragraph

line: Conclusion
label: heading

line: Again, sometimes papers have to be long. But often they don't, and the problem is usually
label: paragraph

line: long introductions and conclusions that go far beyond the needs of the paper.
label: paragraph

line: Language education has clearly taken its tradition from the humanities, which favors
label: paragraph

line: dissertation-style prose, rather than the sciences, where papers are usually much shorter.
label: paragraph

line: It is probably no coincidence that citation rates in the sciences are much higher: Hamilton
label: paragraph

line: (1991) reported that about 91% of papers published in atomic, molecular and chemical
label: paragraph

line: physics, and 86% in virology had been cited at least once. In language and linguistics,
label: paragraph

line: only 20% had been cited and in American literature, less than 1%.
